item.title: For those about to LAB...⚡
item.description: Showcase how to use Cisco IOL in your containerlabs using netlab to orchestrate the provisioning of the infra and Kentik for the traffic visibility and monitoring use cases.

item.title: If this ain't a modern NMS, then what is?
item.description: Leveraging Event Driven Ansible (EDA) and Kentik platform to achieve a simple use case: Ad-hoc shipping of streaming telemetry metrics into Kentik NMS. We are going to see how we can leverage Kentik’s EDA to start collecting ST metrics once mitigations are fired up in the Portal

item.title: K~ustom Metrics in Kentik NMS
item.description: Showcasing the capabilities of Kentik NMS to define custom metrics and display them in the Portal. We are going to see how to configure Kentik’s Universal agent to poll custom SNMP and ST metrics from devices and display them in Metrics Explorer in the Portal

item.title: IOS-XR :: Get Your XPATHs, Get Your XPATHs Honey
item.description: Finally, two useful commands to derive the YANG model and XPATH for XR telemetry from the box itself

item.title: k8s Ansible
item.description: Yet another post about using ansible to provision a kubernetes single control node cluster with kubeadm. We start off by manually provisioning the linux VMs in EVE-NG with a pre-defined username/passwd and dynamic IP addresses. Ansible takes care all the automation tasks to deploy the cluster on the VMs.

item.title: Proxy or not...here I come...
item.description: In some cases, it would be practical to enable or disable the use of the proxy server before running certain commands in bash. This post will show you two methods of utilising the proxy environment variables in bash in an ad-hoc way.

item.title: Kube my router up! - Last Part
item.description: Final part of testing google’s KNE - Installing and using kne_cli to build topologies using srlinux and cEOS.

item.title: Kube my router up! - Part Two
item.description: This is the second part of a three-part blog post around google’s Kubernetes based Network Emulation (KNE) software. In this part, I am showing how to deploy a k8s cluster with a single control node using kubeadm over the VMs created during the first part.

item.title: Kube my router up! - Part One
item.description: This is the first part of a three-part blog post around google’s Kubernetes based Network Emulation (KNE) software. In this part, I am showing how to create the VM nodes in EVE-NG using cloud images that will later host the k8s cluster.
